title: Can I have a chance to get into top graduate schools with GPA 3.5? - Quora
tags: Grade Point Average and Graduate School Admissions
Grade Point Average and University Admissions

response.answer_text: It’s premature to use the word “hurt.” You’ve got 3 more years in which to bring the GPAa bit higher. So…find out a few answers from your undergraduate advisor. Does your college offer “Freshman Forgiveness”? Many schools will permit a student to retake a freshman course in their summer school or sophomore year and record only the higher grade. Ask NOW because some summer sessions begin in mid-July and there might be time to retake one or two courses.Does your school offer tutoring for any courses? Sign up for it and don’t wait until midterms to do so. Get tutoring in as many of your classes as possible and buckle down to the extra work and time that is required.Does your school offer mentoring by faculty members or by graduate students? Develop relationships with mentors who can give you advice. If possible, select tenured faculty as mentors: they ultimately will become those persons to whom you turn for letters of recommendation and if they’ve known you for several years they can truthfully write strong letters attesting to your diligence, responsibility, intellectual curiousity, etc. Please note that if these faculty members did their advanced degrees at the institutions at which you wish to study, letters from such alumni can often tip the balance in favor of your admission to the school.Consider applying for entry-level unpaid internships at companies where you will be in an EE environment: the exposure, the contacts, will all be valuable for you.Last ditch effort: Chances are your 1st year professors graded you generously. Possibly they graded you on clear criteria that were set out in their syllabus, and the grade you received was exactly what you deserved. But sometimes professors grade on a curve. If that is the case with one of your courses, ask the professor for an appointment to review the basis on which your grade was calculated. If your attendance was excellent/perfect, if your quizzes, exams, labs, etc. would bring your grade up, request that the professor reconsider giving you the grade you actually earned, rather than the curved grade. Ask whether they would consider submitting a “Change of Grade Form” citing “computational error” as the reason for the slightly higher grade. Whatever you do, DON’T approach the prof with some absolute bullshit like “I’m a straight-A student.” No, you’re not. Not anymore. Or “I need an A to keep my: visa/scholarship/loan.” If so, you should have earned the “A”. And you didn’t. We don’t give away good grades. YOU have to earn them. But we do have some discretion. We are honest, decent people. We are not out to take your tuition money (WE don’t get it) and fail you. We DO want you to succeed, but YOU must earn it. IF you have, then ask the prof to reconsider. If they refuse and if the grade you earned is a close call (you earned a B but received a B-) do NOT appeal the grade to the Dean’s office. If the Prof refuses and the grade you earned is substantially better than what you received (you got a B- but earned an A-) then take it to the Dean after first entreating your Prof. The Dean will NEVER force the Prof to change the grade but neither does the Proff want to appear unreasonable in the eyes of the Dean.So, here are the 5 things you ought to do. What you should NOT do is give up. You now know how hard you need to work to succeed. Do it.

A2A. A GPA of 3.5 is in the lower range of most top graduate schools - the average GPA is around 3.9 - so you would need a near perfect GRE scores where the GRE makes up for a low GPA. Some universities do not consider the GRE as a substitution for GPA, so you will need to check with the universities website to see how the GRE is used. If you get to where your accomplishments are evaluated, it will be your SOP supported by your LORs that makes or breaks your application when compared to the other applicants. Your accomplishments must standout if you expect to be admitted to a top university. For a discussion of how to target research groups, see James Leland Harp's post in My admissions posts

I think maybe you’re taking it all a bit too seriously. If you’re not careful, you’ll miss the full experience of college. Just like you likely missed out on being a kid. I was obsessed with the future like you, once, and thankfully snapped out of it before I missed the present. Do do your best, my friend. Delve into your subject. Immerse yourself. But let graduate school be worried about when it’s time. Stressing yourself into an ulcer will not help your grades. And you cannot spend your entire life sleeping 4 hours a week. Learn first, what your operating level is. Endevour to improve, to be sure, but don’t bust your hind parts to get into a school that will kill you, or worse, ruin that which makes you YOU.

Nope. You’ll also usually need a GRE score, letters of recommendation, and a statement of purpose. The strength of your current program, the reputation of your letter writers and your publication record (if any) will also be taken into account. To do a bit of level-setting: coming from a pretty-good program with ok recommendation letters and a couple of marginal publications will not get you into a top-10 department, even with a 4.0.

More important: have you been involved in independent research as an undergraduate? For many of the top schools this is often the first question. The reason is that the skills you need as a graduate student are very different and a GPA is not the best predictor of success.

I got into the top sociology doctoral program on the planet (Wisconsin-Madison) with an undergrad GPA of 3.34. But I went to Reed College. If I'd gone to the local commuter campus of Purdue in my home town, I never would've got close to admitted at UW and certainly wouldn't have got the fellowship I had there.

In theory, the minimum GPA required is 3.0. So you meet the minimum requirements. It all depends who else is applying. You compete with other, very accomplished students, many from top schools already. A GPA on its own is not enough information.
